section.names: tutorial\ 8\ python:\ encapsulating\ components\ and\ working\ with\ parents tutorial8_py
section.title: Tutorial 8 Python: Encapsulating components and working with parents
section.paragraph: The outline for this tutorial is shown on the Tutorial 8 page. These are the Python instructions. For the same tutorial in C++ please see the Tutorial 8 in C++ page instead.

list_item.paragraph: tutorial8.py Either the skeleton code, or ..
../utilities/tutorial_utilities.py Utility functions for use in the tutorials.
If you did not complete Tutorial 7 you can download the file created there: ../resources/tutorial8_MembraneModel.cellml

section.title: 0: Setup
section.paragraph: We’ll start by creating the utilities that we’ll use later on.

container.paragraph: 0.a As previously, create:

list_item.paragraph: a Parser instance to deserialise the models
a Validator instance for debugging purposes
a Model model to attach everything into

section.title: 1: Read the membrane component

container.paragraph: 1.a Just as you did in Tutorial 6 TODO CHECK for the potassium channel, parse the tutorial8_MembraneModel.cellml file and save the deserialised model to a new model instance (not the one you’ve already created above - a new one). If you’d like, use the print_model_to_terminal utility function to check it has been read correctly, and the validator to make sure that it is valid on its own.

section.paragraph: At this stage you will have two Model items - an empty one you created in earlier which will become the combined model, and the one you’ve just read from the file.

container.paragraph: 1.b Since you’ll want to reuse the membrane component from the imported potassium channel model within your combined model, you need to retrieve it from the imported model and add it to the combined one. Note that you will need to retrieve the membrane component from the model and use the clearParent() function to detach it from the membrane model before you add it to your combined model.
Note that the addComponent and addVariable functions have a built-in check which will prevent them from having one parent:

list_item.paragraph: if a Variable or Component has a nullptr parent, then calling an addComponent or addVariable function will insert that item into the parent component.
if a Variable or Component already has a parent() component, then nothing will be changed.
if you need to move parent ownership of a variable or a component you need to first call the clearParent() function before adding it to the new parent.

section.paragraph: Before going much further it’s probably a good idea to understand what it is that you’ve just imported. For a full description of the biological theory, please see the Hodgkin-Huxley background document. You should be able to see the variables and maths inside the imported component by simply printing the combined model to the screen.

container.paragraph: 1.c Print the MathML2 string from the membrane component in your combined model and check it represents the equations below. You can check back to the earlier Tutorial 5, step 2 if need be.

1.d Call the validator to check the combined model. At this stage we expect to see errors related to missing units: we have imported a component containing maths and variables, both of which reference units that we haven’t yet included in the combined model:

section.literal_block:
The validator has found 13 errors! Validator error[0]: Description: Variable 'V' has an invalid units reference 'mV' that does not correspond with a standard unit or units in the variable's parent component or model. See section 11.1.1.2 in the CellML specification.
...
Validator error[8]: Description: Math has a cn element with a cellml:units attribute 'microA_per_cm2' that is not a valid reference to units in the model 'Tutorial8_HHModel' or a standard unit.

container.paragraph: 1.e Use a loop to import all of the units from the the potassium channel model into the combined model.
1.f Validate the combined model once more and check that it is now free of errors.

section.title: 2: Read the sodium channel component
section.paragraph: In Tutorial 7 you created a component to represent the behaviour of a gated sodium gate and stored it inside a model.

container.paragraph: 2.a As in step 1.a, retrieve the sodium channel model from the file you created in Tutorial 7, or use the resources/tutorial7_SodiumChannelModel.cellml file.

2.b As in step 1.b, retrieve the sodium channel component and add it to the membrane component created in step 1. Remember to clear its parent first! Print the combined model to the terminal using the condensed function print_encapsulation_structure_to_terminal and notice that the “child” components encapsulated by the sodium channel component - the mGate and hGate components - are imported as well.

section.literal_block: Model 'Tutorial8_HHModel' has 1 components - Component 'membrane' has 1 child components - Component 'sodiumChannel' has 2 child components - Component 'mGate' has 0 child components - Component 'hGate' has 0 child components

container.paragraph: 2.c Call the validator to check the combined model so far. At this stage we expect to see two kinds of errors:

list_item.paragraph: errors related to units missing from the combined model, as before.

TODO errors related to the equivalent variables connections between the sodium channel component (which is now in the combined model) and the environment component (which is still in the sodium channel model). Since the components are no longer adjacent in the encapsulation hierarchy, they cannot be connected.

container.paragraph: 2.d Import the missing units into the combined model from the sodium channel model. Revalidate the combined model and pay attention to errors related to the units.

Note that you cannot have units with duplicate names in a model: if you have simply imported all of the units from the sodium channel model, then there will be double-ups. You can use the model.hasUnits function to check whether a Units item with the same name already exists in a model before importing it.

section.paragraph: After validation you should see that there are no more errors related to units, but you will still need to address the illegal connections between variables in the newly-moved sodium channel component and the old environment component in the sodium channel model.
section.literal_block: **PUT ERRORS HERE WHEN VALIDATOR IS WORKING**
section.paragraph: Recall the idiom you used in Tutorial 5 to create the connections between equivalent variables; the same can be done in reverse here to remove the equivalence between two variables:
section.literal_block: # Retrieving the pointers to the variables via their names and removing an equivalence libcellml.Variable.removeEquivalence( sodium_channel_model.component("environment").variable("t"), sodium_channel.variable("t") )

container.paragraph: 2.e Disconnect any equivalences between variables in the environment component of the sodium channel model, from those inside the newly-moved sodium channel component in the combined model.
2.f Validate the combined model to see that it is now free of errors.

section.title: 3: Import the potassium channel component
section.paragraph: Now we simply need to repeat the same process for our potassium channel component and add it to the combined model.

container.paragraph: 3.a-b Repeat the process above to import the potassium channel component that was created in Tutorial 5 into the membrane component. Note that if you did not complete that tutorial you can simply copy the resources/tutorial6_PotassiumComponentModel.cellml file.
3.c Use the validator to alert you to the errors at this stage.

list_item.paragraph: either import all the units under their original names from the potassium channel as well,
or rename the units throughout the potassium channel component’s variables and maths.

section.paragraph: Here we’ll go with the latter to illustrate the process, and to create a more compact model description.

container.paragraph: 3.d Use the examples below to rename the units referenced by variables inside this component. This is straightforward:

section.literal_block: # Setting the names of units to be consistent with those in the combined model potassium_channel.variable("t").setUnits("ms") potassium_channel.component("nGate").variable("t").setUnits("ms") ... etc ...
section.paragraph: You’ll also need to replace the units of any constants in the MathML blocks of the components as well. This is not quite as straightforward, but we’ve provided a utility function switch_units_in_maths which does a string replacement for the unit names. The function can be used like this:
section.literal_block:
# The switch_units_in_maths function's definition in tutorial_utilities.py: new_maths = switch_units_in_maths(old_maths, old_units, new_units)
# Switch the name of the units referred to in a MathML string # Retrieve the MathML string from the component n_gate_maths = potassium_channel.component("nGate").math()
# Switch the unit names in the string n_gate_maths = switch_units_in_maths(n_gate_maths, "millivolt", "mV")
# Repeat for all units ... # Remember to add the corrected string back into the component when you're done

container.paragraph: Note that a simple string replacement for any and all occurrences of the in string within the maths string with the out string could cause problems when the in string is a substring of another unit name. In order to be sure that only full name matches for units are replaced, we exploit the fact that the units names in the MathML string will be in quotation marks, and include " blocks on either side of the in and out strings for safety. You will therefore need to substitute whole names only for this function to work.
3.e Rename the units in the MathML strings as needed. Remember that you’ll need to re-add the corrected MathML string to the component when you’re done:

section.literal_block: Switched units 'millivolt' for units 'mV' Switched units 'millisecond' for units 'ms' Switched units 'per_millisecond' for units 'per_ms' Switched units 'per_millivolt_millisecond' for units 'per_mV_ms' Switched units 'milliS_per_cm2' for units 'mS_per_cm2'

container.paragraph: 3.f As you did in step 2.e, disconnect the variable equivalences which link the imported component to the old environment in the potassium channel model, and validate that the combined model is now free of errors.

4.a If you know the tune, sing along! Import the leakage component from the model in resources/tutorial8_LeakageModel.cellml and add it to the membrane component. Use the validator to debug and make any adjustments you need to until your combined model is free of errors.

section.title: 5: Create the environment component
section.paragraph: Now your model should have the encapsulation structure shown below. You can check this in the same way as you did in step 2.b.
section.literal_block: Model 'Tutorial8_HHModel' has 1 components - Component 'membrane' has 3 child components - Component 'sodiumChannel' has 2 child components - Component 'mGate' has 0 child components - Component 'hGate' has 0 child components - Component 'potassiumChannel' has 1 child components - Component 'nGate' has 0 child components - Component 'leakageCurrent' has 0 child components
section.paragraph: The final component you need to add is an environment component for this combined model. This contains the time t of the simulation as well as the membrane voltage V.

container.paragraph: 5.a Create a new Component to represent the environment, and add it to your combined model as a top-level component.
5.b Include the local environment variables that you’ll need, including their units, and validate that your model is free of errors.

section.title: 6: Connect the equivalent variables
section.paragraph: The encapsulation structure for this model has several tiers, as shown in the diagram below:
section.literal_block: ____ HodgkinHuxleyModel | |____ environment (V, t) | |____ membrane (V, t) | |____ sodiumChannel (V, t, h, m) | | | |____ hGate (h, V, t) | | | |____ mGate (m, V, t) | |____ potassiumChannel (n, V, t) | | | |____ nGate (n, V, t) | |____ leakageCurrent (V)
section.paragraph: The encapsulation structure above includes the variables in each component which are shared with an adjacent component.

container.paragraph: 6.a Set the equivalent variables according to the diagram above. Note that the gates remain connected to the sodium and potassium channels and don’t need to be added again.
6.b Using the same interface type rules as in Tutorial 7, set the interface type for the missing interfaces.
6.c Validate that the final model is free of errors.

section.title: 7: Define the driving function
section.paragraph: In contrast to earlier tutorials, this simulation will not be a voltage clamp experiment, but will model instead the response to a stimulus current in the membrane. You’ve already got some maths inside the membrane component which you imported in step 1.b which defined the influence of the total membrane current i_{tot} on the voltage, V. It also defined the total current as the sum of currents in the potassium channel i_K, the sodium channel i_{Na}, the leakage current i_L, as well as an as-yet unused variable, the stimulus current i_{stim}. To constrain the mathematics completely, you’ll need to add a definition for this stimulus current.

container.paragraph: 7.a Create a MathML2 equation to represent the stimulus current having a value of 100 mA/cm^2 between 1ms < t < 1.2ms and zero otherwise.

7.b Because there is already a maths block (with <math>...</math> tags at both ends) you can’t just add new equation on the end of what’s there - it needs to be added before the final </math> tag. There’s a utility function to help with this which can be called using new_maths = insert_into_mathml_string(old_maths, maths_to_include)

section.literal_block: # Insert the new MathML string before the closing </math> tag membrane_math = membrane.math() membrane_math = insert_into_mathml_string(membrane_math, stimulus_math) # Remember to add the new maths back into your component as well ...

section.title: 8: Output the model
section.paragraph: Finally you’re ready to write the model ready for simulation. You know the drill!
